results.abstract: In this lesson, students explore education requirements for different professions, and define the skills and knowledge that adults use in their everyday lives.
results.snippet: In this lesson, students explore education requirements for different professions, and define the skills and knowledge that adults use in their everyday lives.

byline.original: By MICHELLE SALE and JESSICA LEVINE

results.lead_paragraph: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

results.abstract: Public Lives interview with Forrest R Taylor, chief of staff for New York City Council and spokesman for new speaker, Gifford Miller; photo (M)

headline.main: Sparring With the Old Boss, on Behalf of the New

results.snippet: THE nickname Teddy Bear was bestowed, allegedly in all sincerity, by his baby-faced new boss, Gifford Miller, the City Council speaker, and it has been hard to shake. Rumor has it Forrest R. Taylor, chief of staff for the City Council and chief...
results.lead_paragraph: THE nickname Teddy Bear was bestowed, allegedly in all sincerity, by his baby-faced new boss, Gifford Miller, the City Council speaker, and it has been hard to shake. Rumor has it Forrest R. Taylor, chief of staff for the City Council and chief mouthpiece for Mr. Miller, would prefer to be known by a manlier moniker and even went so far as to suggest a replacement nickname: Turbo! But Teddy Bear it is. As Mr. Taylor, 40 and immaculately attired behind spiffy navy blue suspenders, is fond of reminding himself, what the speaker says, goes. ''I work for a politician, so it's all about his vision,'' says Mr. Taylor, feet propped on his desk, hands clasped behind his head, sweat stains on display at the end of another endless day at City Hall. He claims his five months on this job feel like a lifetime; he is counting the hours to a week's vacation in Brazil. Not that he's complaining.

results.abstract: Review panel charged with identifying research priorities for National Aeronautics and Space Administration says that if International Space Station is to be considered scientific project that produces first-rate research, it will have to grow beyond current plans; original size and scope of station were cut back because of cost overruns that were as much as $5 billion over $25 billion designated by Congress (M)

headline.main: Panel Asserts Reduced Space Station Plans Will Limit Scientific Work

results.snippet: If the International Space Station is to be considered a scientific project that produces first-rate research, it will have to grow beyond current plans, which reduced its original size and scope, a review panel said today.    The panel says there is...
results.lead_paragraph: If the International Space Station is to be considered a scientific project that produces first-rate research, it will have to grow beyond current plans, which reduced its original size and scope, a review panel said today. The panel says there is more than enough substantial work to do on the space station if the proper equipment is aboard and enough crew work time is allocated. The panel is an independent task force charged with identifying research priorities for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration and the space station in particular.

results.abstract: Baseball legend Ted Williams's daughter Barbara Joyce Williams Ferrell asks President George W Bush and others to help keep her brother John Henry Williams from cryonically freezing father's body (M)

headline.main: Williams's Daughter Asks For Aid Against Freezing

results.snippet: Ted Williams's oldest daughter is urging John Glenn, President Bush and former President George Bush to help stop her half brother from keeping their father's body frozen.    Glenn and Williams flew together when both were fighter pilots in the...
results.lead_paragraph: Ted Williams's oldest daughter is urging John Glenn, President Bush and former President George Bush to help stop her half brother from keeping their father's body frozen. Glenn and Williams flew together when both were fighter pilots in the Korean War. Williams was in the midst of a Hall of Fame career with the Boston Red Sox and later worked on the Bush presidential campaigns. Glenn went on to become the first American astronaut to orbit the earth and later was elected to the United States Senate.

results.abstract: Ten novelists describe memorable endings of books they have read (special section, Favorites) (S)

headline.main: Endings; Skipping to the Last Page

results.snippet: Jane Smiley      Endings don't usually stick in your mind very much. Often there's a certain piquancy or grace about the last paragraphs but in some ways it's not as interesting as whatever set up the beginning and the rest of the book. I went back...
results.lead_paragraph: Jane Smiley Endings don't usually stick in your mind very much. Often there's a certain piquancy or grace about the last paragraphs but in some ways it's not as interesting as whatever set up the beginning and the rest of the book. I went back and looked at my favorite book, Dickens's ''Our Mutual Friend'' and that ending was very nice. He kind of stuck it to the petty people in the book at the end. There's an Icelandic story that I really like called ''Egil's Saga'' that's about a very bad man -- he's a warrior and he does a lot of ill-turns in the course of his life and the saga ends with him as a very old man being pushed around and reprimanded by the servant women for being in the way. I really love that ending.

results.abstract: NASA officials, citing need to repair cracks in fuel line and scheduling problems, say first shuttle mission to include Israeli astronaut is likely to be delayed until at least end of year; manager Ron Dittemore explains repair options (S)

headline.main: Delay Likely for Shuttle Mission With Israeli

results.snippet: NASA officials said today that it was highly likely that the first shuttle mission to include an Israeli astronaut would have to be delayed until at least the end of the year.     The mission, which had been scheduled for liftoff today, was delayed...
results.lead_paragraph: NASA officials said today that it was highly likely that the first shuttle mission to include an Israeli astronaut would have to be delayed until at least the end of the year. The mission, which had been scheduled for liftoff today, was delayed after engineers found cracks in a fuel line, a problem that has grounded the shuttle fleet. The mission has drawn considerable interest because of the inclusion of the Israeli Air Force pilot, Col. Ilan Ramon, and the tight security that entailed.

results.abstract: George Vecsey Sports of The Times column discusses tribute to Boston Red Sox legend Ted Williams at Fenway Park, where extended family including former teammates, media, Marines and fans gather to honor one of greatest hitters to play baseball; photos (M)

headline.main: Sports of The Times; Extended Family Unites in Tribute

results.snippet: HIS family paid tribute to Ted Williams last night  his extended family, old teammates and Red Sox fans from all over New England, some of whom had seen him play, most of whom merely marveled at who he was.    The family congregated in Fenway Park,...
results.lead_paragraph: HIS family paid tribute to Ted Williams last night his extended family, old teammates and Red Sox fans from all over New England, some of whom had seen him play, most of whom merely marveled at who he was. The family congregated in Fenway Park, that national treasure that has not changed markedly since Williams began lashing home runs in 1939.

results.abstract: Prince Ahmed bin Salman, Saudi Arabian businessman who owned War Emblem, winner of this year's Kentucky Derby and Preakness Stakes, and Point Given, thoroughbred racing's 2001 horse of the year, dies at age 43; photo (M)

headline.main: Prince Ahmed bin Salman, Top Horse Owner, Dies at 43

results.snippet: Prince Ahmed bin Salman, the Saudi Arabian businessman who owned War Emblem, the winner of this year's Kentucky Derby and Preakness Stakes, and Point Given, thoroughbred racing's 2001 horse of the year, died yesterday at a hospital in Riyadh. He was...
results.lead_paragraph: Prince Ahmed bin Salman, the Saudi Arabian businessman who owned War Emblem, the winner of this year's Kentucky Derby and Preakness Stakes, and Point Given, thoroughbred racing's 2001 horse of the year, died yesterday at a hospital in Riyadh. He was 43. The cause was a heart attack, said Terence Collier, a consultant to the Thoroughbred Corporation, bin Salman's California-based racing stable.

results.abstract: Man in the News article on New York City's new schools chancellor Joel Irwin Klein (M)

headline.kicker: THE NEW SCHOOLS CHANCELLOR: MAN IN THE NEWS
headline.main: A Path Back to School -- Joel Irwin Klein

results.snippet: New York City's new schools chancellor is not an easy man to shop for. When he stepped down as assistant attorney general in charge of antitrust enforcement at the Justice Department in 2000, having led the government's prosecution of Microsoft, his...
results.lead_paragraph: New York City's new schools chancellor is not an easy man to shop for. When he stepped down as assistant attorney general in charge of antitrust enforcement at the Justice Department in 2000, having led the government's prosecution of Microsoft, his senior staff members huddled about a farewell gift. Though their boss, Joel I. Klein, had spent almost his entire career in Washington, he never gave up a certain directness of manner that many associate with New York City. He is impatient, friends say, with the paraphernalia that surrounds powerful people in both cities.
